title: Are Stephen King books ok for 14 year olds? - Quora

response.answer_text: Here is what I recommend to parents or guardians who ask questions like this: you have to watch/read it yourself to make that distinction. Every parent/guardian is going to have different convictions about what they allow their kid to watch/read. I cannot, nor can anyone else, tell you what is or isn’t okay for your 14 year old. And in the event that this question is coming from the teen, I would recommend that you speak to your parent/guardian if you are curious about watching/reading it and see what they have to say about it. If you “aren’t allowed” to watch/read it, and you do it anyways, just know that you will have to deal with any repercussions of that action. Everyone has a different standard and different opinion on things like this, and I always recommend that the adult in authority read or watch it carefully before they decide. That way, if there are issues, they can potentially address them with their teen in a mature conversation rather than simply hearing something about the movie or book and banning it altogether, or allowing things to be watched/read out of ignorance that could damage the child/teen. I, personally, loved It in every form. It’s one of my all time favorites, and I think that someone at the age of 14 could handle the more graphic and mature material without issue. But that’s my opinion-- and in this case, my opinion doesn’t count because I’m not the adult in authority.

I read it when I was 13 and if someone had prohibited me from doing so, I may not have found my love for books. It was the first big novel I ever finished and I learned an important lesson about setting and accomplishing a difficult goal. That would be the groundwork for hundreds of books that I would go on to read over the next 25 years. It may have been the first catalyst that put me on a path to achieving a 4 year degree. Sure there’s some scary stuff, foul language and sexual content in it, but don’t let the micro content of the work stand in the way of opening up a world of books to a young person. I went on to consume every work by Stephen King and many other books by many other authors. Reading recreationally as a teenager provides a distinct advantage in reading comprehension and writing composition skills. The content of the books that a 14 year old reads is far less important than the fact that they want to read something at all. if you’re a parent, you can’t control what your children are exposed to and when it comes to literature, you shouldn’t try. Encourage them to read anything that interests them, but make sure you’re talking to them about it, so you can help them interpret what they’re reading.

I read my first SK novel when I was 12 or so, and I’m still as excited to read his latest works now as I was then. The fact that your child wants to read an actual book is already a good thing. I say, let him or her read SK if he/she wants to. Some of the stories may contain graphic violent scenes, but in my opinion, not as bad as what other authors write. If you’re introducing your child to SK, I suggest to get these first, and let them decide if they want to read more later on: The Eyes of the DragonPet SematarySalem’s LotThe Talisman (with Peter Straub)InsomniaThese are my most favorite novels of SK as well. I guarantee that your child will love them. Happy reading!

Age is not really a determinant for maturity. So, unfortunately my answer is not going to be as straightfoward as you probably hoped. I say it depends. If you’re like me at 14, then you in no way want to get near anything horror, especially books as I find them even more terrifying due to their ability to make you create your own images. In fact, if you’re like me at any age, you want no part of that. But otherwise if you feel that you’re up to it, then go ahead. I would advise slowly getting yourself into horror novels though, perhaps ones more appropriate for “beginners” and then building your way up to King. I hope that when you do read him, you enjoy the experience.

I would say if you can handle it, but probably a NO. I started reading stephen king when I was about 14 to, my first novels being The Shining, Carrie, The Running Man, The Green Mile, and The Stand. He writes fantastic books, but most of them (i’m looking at you, The Stand, and Under the Dome) I filled with 1. Excessive swearing 2. heavy sexual themes/sexuality/rape and 3. Brutal and disturbing violence. If you are ok with excessive amounts of these mature topics then go for it! Great books, although most of them are pretty screwed up

My personal opinion is that one can read anything one feels the need to read… I do not stop myself from reading something that I would want to know aboutJust make sure if I can learn or take away something positive from the reading… if the answer is in the affirmative then it is on my reading listNever stop myself from keeping away a book just because I am not done reading it especially if it does not keep me interested in going further…(not talking about academic books here)There is no age limitations for reading… if grasping the content makes sense to me… I really doubt it should not be read and known…Enjoy reading!!!

IT was rather scary for this 57 year old but it depends on whether you get scared really easily AND if the parents are okay with you reading a book by Stephen King. The book gets much more graphic about the murders as well as some other aspects of the story that were not included in Part 1 of the new movie version. The TV version edited out much of the more violent parts but left enough for the imagination. I’d ask a parent about this. I’d say 13 or 14 might be a bit young for Stephen King. I could not have handled “IT” at 14 but my son could have (I’m easily scared by some horror stuff) with no problems. I would say wait until 16 or so. Yes, that is not what you want to hear but trust me. The book will still be around and will be much richer than the movie.

I’ve read them. He is a masterful story teller. A 14 year old reading books? In today’s world? Reading and thinking? Using their imagination? Not just clicking and swiping? Stephen King is fine. But that’s really not important. If a 14 year old is discovering a love of books and reading, I’d be giving them as many books as they want.

By the time I was 13 I had read all of Dickens, Galsworthy, Austen, Bronte, Powl, Wodehouse, Hardy, Conan Doyle, Scott, Stevenson, Du Maurier, Orwell, and Lee. And hosts of ghost stories, potboiling detective novels, “Shockers", and murder yarns. As well as bunches of biography and arms of travel books. You should have no problem with King, who is a massive believer in both story and meticulous language. Bit long-winded, though.

Well, it depends on the book, and the 14-year-old, I guess. I read Pet Sematary when I was 12, and straight after that I tackled IT, Rage, Nightmares and Dreamscapes, Christine, Firestarter and Carrie, and I had no problem with them at all... but I am glad I didn't pick up Salem's Lot or The Stand until a bit later. :)

I would say the movie is, provided the 14-year-old has had some exposure to the horror genre. It has a few jump-scares and some swearing, but nothing too extreme. The book, it would depend on the child. The first chapters detail the beating of a homosexual man. It could be confusing or traumatic for some at that age. I read It when I was 11 (the first time) and kind of wish I had waited. I didn’t understand much of what was happening.

I read my first Stephen King novel at age 9, maybe 10. I read about 4, give or take, before tackling IT between grades 5 and 6. That one was way too mature for me. I finished it, but I didn't pick up King again till 15 or so. I'd say it depends on the book. But I'd also say that if a child wants to read, you let them read. Period. That's my humble opinion.
Depends on the maturity level of the 14 year old? If the teen has a good grasp on reality and knows the difference between real life and fantasy, then my answer is yes.
Yesy daughter started reading Stephen king at 10 years old

l would suggest reading Dracula by Bram Stroker, first. If that does not give you nightmares, then, if you really want to, read King. However, I would suggest you read the greats of science-fiction and get your creative juices flowing. Then come back to Stoker, et al. later.
